title: Google I/O: Big changes coming for SEOs with ubiquitous AI
text: Google’s annual I/O event got off to an exciting start with its keynote. In summary: AI is now ubi
summary: Google's annual I/O event highlighted the pervasive influence of AI across all of the company's core products, with significant implications for SEO professionals, content creators and developers. The keynote introduced new features in core Google products such as Google Search and Workspace, including the "Help me write" tool, which leverages AI to generate content. Automated writing tools for SEO will have an advantage in scoring content and generating synthetic content. For creatives, the new range of image editing tools could become the next generation of clip art, while conversational AI integrated into the search function will enable more engagement within Google's properties. The name of the game for website owners will be to ensure their content appears in both search results and generated responses.

title: Reverse engineering Dell iDRAC to get rid of GPU throttling
summary: The content is a commit to a repository about reverse engineering Dell iDRAC to remove GPU throttling. The commit does not belong to any branch on the repository and it may belong to a fork outside of the repository. The message also includes instructions on how to refresh your session if necessary.

title: Story: Redis and its creator antirez
text:
繁體中文版請按這裡 This article is translated from the original  Chinese edition . 
 
 In the world of data
summary: Redis, the popular database system used by nearly all web services today, owes its unique design to the innovative thinking of Salvatore Sanfilippo, also known as "antirez," and his preference for low-level data structure interactions over higher-level ones. Antirez's interest in computers began as a child when his family got their first personal computer, and he started programming in BASIC. He later honed his skills by discovering a vulnerability in the Unix ping program and posting his findings on the Bugtraq mailing list, and working at SECLAB, a cybersecurity company where he created hping and invented the Idle Scan attack. Redis was born out of antirez's desire to create a memory database for LLOOGG, his web analytics tool for bloggers, after running into performance issues with MySQL. Redis' popularity skyrocketed after being adopted by GitHub, Instagram, and Twitter, and antirez continued to develop it through its various versions. In January 2020, he stepped down as the project's developer and maintainer, feeling burned out after a decade of devotion and struggling to balance art and utility. He has since written a science fiction book about artificial intelligence called Wohpe, while Redis released version 7.0, its first major version since his departure.

title: Expensive energy may have killed more Europeans than Covid-19 last winter
text: A fter russia  invaded Ukraine in February 2022, Vladimir Putin weaponised his country’s energy supp
summary: High energy prices caused by Russia's cut in gas exports to Europe may have contributed to excess deaths during the winter of 2022-23, according to a study by The Economist. Comparing actual deaths with the number expected using mortality from 2015-19, 149,000 excess deaths were recorded in 28 European countries between November 2022 and February 2023. The 7.8% increase, which included some 60,000 Covid-19 deaths, was likely also influenced by the weather, but the study said that a rise of €0.10 per kWh in electricity prices led to a rise of around 2.2% in weekly mortality.

title: The World’s Greatest Freediver (2021)
text: That these divers orient their lives around the oceans, around the planet's best spots to dive, arou
summary: Alexey Molchanov, a noted freediver, embodies a devotional approach to exploring the depths of the sea, driven by an intense passion and fascination for the ocean's riches. Alexey was drawn to this kind of experiential living while searching for new ways to explore the world and challenge himself; previously, he had been involved in a plethora of activities as a child, such as swimming, chess, violin, and tae kwon do. Alexey's mother, Natalia, was also a freediving enthusiast, who had built a freediving school in Moscow and broken world records in the sport. When Alexey graduated from university, he worked with Natalia, who passed away during a training dive in 2015. In addition to running the freediving school and the business, Molchanovs, Alexey continues to teach his mother's techniques of diving and deconcentration, which allow individuals to expand their capacity to operate without air and face life's challenges with greater resilience.

title: Infosec company pwned by 4chan user
text:
infosec company owned completely by 4chan user risk visualize deez nuts 
 yesterday evening an ano
summary: An anonymous 4chan user claimed to have completely owned the cyber security risk assessment company, Optimeyes, which focuses on intellectual property theft. The company's focus on visualizing and helping prevent IP theft makes it all so much more ironic how completely they have been hacked. The leak contains all the source code for the Optimeyes platform, tons of customer data, fully trained ML models Optimeyes is built on, and tons of hardcoded credentials for their infrastructure. The leak also revealed that Optimeyes did not secure its own systems, which is a significant irony. The leak most probably came from a Jenkins instance belonging to Optimeyes that mistakenly pointed to the Bitbucket credentials in its URL. The leak can be a great and hilarious lesson in cybersecurity, and the probably highest value assets in the leak are customer data, which includes server inventories and vulnerability scans from inside customer networks. The leak could be devastating for Optimeyes as they lost massive amounts of customer data, and all their intellectual property has leaked. It seems that the leak was done for 'lulz' more than anything else.

title: Google I/O: Big changes coming for SEOs with ubiquitous AI
text: Google’s annual I/O event got off to an exciting start with its keynote. In summary: AI is now ubi
summary: Google's annual I/O event, focused on AI, highlighted the impact of AI on the core products of the company. The new AI features announced at the event, such as generative AI in the search results, will significantly impact SEO and content marketing. The new updates aim to generate longer user engagement, and Google's shopping graph integration will give users more navigation through product categories, hence marketers must ensure product lists and metadata are optimized to become discoverable. Google's "Help Me Write" feature will write documents with a simple prompt, which is useful for content creators to generate product descriptions, job descriptions and more. Automated writing tools are expected to excel at scoring content and generating content that is not branded as synthetic content from Google. Agencies for content creation will adopt more of an engineering focus in the future. Overall, Google's shift towards AI tools and features is the next evolution in generative AI and will add value to users. As long as there is content on the internet, SEO is not dead. While traditional SEO practices will apply, there will likely be increased importance on structured data, knowledge graphs, and quality content to appear in the generated responses to content.

title: Reverse engineering Dell iDRAC to get rid of GPU throttling
summary: The content is a repository on GitHub with the title "Reverse Engineering Dell iDrac to Get Rid of GPU Throttling". The repository contains an effort to reverse engineer Dell's Integrated Dell Remote Access Controller (iDrac) to disable GPU throttling. This is done through modifying the firmware of the iDrac chip which controls many features of Dell servers, including fan speed and temperature sensors. The repository offers technical details and code for those interested in this type of project.

title: Story: Redis and its creator antirez
text:
繁體中文版請按這裡 This article is translated from the original  Chinese edition . 
 
 In the world of data
summary: Redis is a popular database known for its unique approach in which users directly interact with low-level data structures instead of high-level data representations. Salvatore Sanfilippo, known as antirez, created Redis as an amateur in the database field, but his lack of experience allowed him to bring fresh ideas to the industry. He was sought out by a cybersecurity company called SECLAB, where he invented an attack called Idle Scan and created a tool called hping. antirez also founded his own company called Merzia and built LLOOGG, a web analytics tool that allowed website administrators to track visitors' behavior in real-time. antirez developed Redis, initially using the Tcl programming language before transitioning to C to rewrite it. Redis gained popularity with its early adopters, GitHub, Instagram, and Twitter, and in 2009, VMware became Redis's first major sponsor. Redis has had several new features, and in January 2020, antirez introduced Redis 6.0 at a Redis Day conference. However, in June of that year, antirez announced that he would be stepping down from his role as the developer and maintainer of the Redis project, citing burnout.

title: Expensive energy may have killed more Europeans than Covid-19 last winter
text: A fter russia  invaded Ukraine in February 2022, Vladimir Putin weaponised his country’s energy supp
summary: Last winter, high energy prices may have been responsible for an additional 68,000 deaths across Europe, according to a statistical model built by The Economist. Comparing the actual number of deaths to what was expected based on mortality statistics in the same weeks across 2015-19, they found an excess of 149,000 deaths between November 2022 and February 2023, a 7.8% increase. While nearly 60,000 of these extra deaths were recorded as being caused by Covid-19, the remaining 90,000 could have been caused by a rise in energy prices, which can discourage people from heating their homes properly, leading to respiratory and cardiac problems. It was also found that those countries hit the hardest by a rise in energy prices experienced a corresponding rise in deaths.

title: What if we covered every warehouse in the mountain West with solar panels?
text: In the U.S. there are more than 450,000 warehouses, which collectively have almost 16.4 billion sq
summary: If all the warehouses in the US were covered in solar panels, it could produce enough electricity to power nearly 19.4 million homes, according to research by the Environment America Research and Policy Center. The analysis found that there are more than 450,000 warehouses in the US that collectively have almost 16.4 billion square feet of rooftop space. Colorado has the highest potential for solar energy production, with 8,757 eligible warehouses that could power 372,000 homes. Nevada’s 4,746 warehouses could electrify 253,000 homes and Utah’s 5,035 warehouses 241,000 homes. Generating the full solar potential of all warehouses would also eliminate over 112 million metric tons of CO2 emissions per year, equivalent to taking 30 coal-fired power plants offline.
